elements.content: A series of novel one-dimensional (1D) lanthanide coordination polymers, [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n (Ln = Sm (1), Eu (2), Gd (3), Tb (4), Dy (5), Ho (6), Er (7), Tm (8), Yb (9), or Lu (10); Hpqc = 2-phenyl-4-quinolinecarboxylic acid), have been synthesized via solvothermal reaction at low temperature and then characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Polymers 1–10 are isostructural and feature a 1D chain based on binuclear units in which Ln3+ polyhedra are interconnected by bridging Hpqc ligands and terminal nitrates. The infinite chains are further extended to a three-dimensional supramolecular framework through π···π stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions. This series affords an opportunity to study the lanthanide contraction effect, demonstrating that the sum of Ln–O distances proportional to this contraction follow a quadratic decay as a function of the number n of f electrons. The photoluminescence spectra show that these complexes are highly sensitized by Hpqc and exhibit characteristic Ln3+ (Sm (1), Eu (2), Tb (4), Er (7), and Yb (9)) and ligand centered (Dy (5), Ho (6), Tm (8), and Lu (10)) luminescence in both visible and near-infrared (NIR) regions. The magnetic properties of 4–7 have also been investigated.

Polymers 1-10 are isostructural and feature a 1D chain based on binuclear units in which Ln3+ polyhedra are interconnected by bridging Hpqc ligands and terminal nitrates. The infinite chains are further extended to a three-dimensional supramolecular framework through π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions. This series affords an opportunity to study the lanthanide contraction effect, demonstrating that the sum of Ln-O distances proportional to this contraction follow a quadratic decay as a function of the number n of f electrons. The photoluminescence spectra show that these complexes are highly sensitized by Hpqc and exhibit characteristic Ln3+ (Sm (1), Eu (2), Tb (4), Er (7), and Yb (9)) and ligand centered (Dy (5), Ho (6), Tm (8), and Lu (10)) luminescence in both visible and near-infrared (NIR) regions. The magnetic properties of 4-7 have also been investigated.

elements.content: Reactions of 2-phenyl-4-quinolinecarboxylic acid (Hpqc) with lanthanide nitrates by low-temperature solvothermal method give birth to a series of novel one-dimensional (1D) lanthanide coordination polymers, [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n (Ln = Sm (1), Eu (2), Gd (3), Tb (4), Dy (5), Ho (6), Er (7), Tm (8), Yb (9), or Lu (10)) with multiplex luminescent and magnetic properties.

elements.content: The design of lanthanide complexes has attracted extensive interest during the past decade because of their fascinating architectures and physical properties with widespread applications in sensors, labels for biomolecules, stains for cellular imaging, display devices, redox-active switches, and single-molecule magnets (SMMs). As we know, Ln3+ ions, due to shielding of the 4f orbits by the full 5p66s2 subshells, show characteristic narrow line-like emissions of pure colors in both visible and near-infrared (NIR) regions that are nearly unaffected by the ligand field. Especially, Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes are widely applied as luminescent materials for strong, easily detected emissions in the visible region, while Nd3+, Er3+, and Yb3+ complexes are studied in biological analysis because of their almost transparent NIR emissions in biological issues. Additionally, because of the large number of unpaired 4f electrons and magnetic anisotropy arising from the strong unquenched orbital angular momentum, lanthanide ions, especially heavy ones like Tb3+ and Dy3+, have recently been brought into the field of molecular magnetism. These molecules, such as SMMs and single-chain magnets (SCMs) with magnetic bistability, display slow relaxation of the magnetization at low temperature offering the opportunity to make quantum information devices.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of lanthanide complexes has attracted extensive interest during the past decade because of their fascinating architectures and physical properties with widespread applications in sensors, labels for biomolecules, stains for cellular imaging, display devices, redox-active switches, and single-molecule magnets (SMMs). As we know, Ln3+ ions, due to shielding of the 4f orbits by the full 5p66s2 subshells, show characteristic narrow line-like emissions of pure colors in both visible and near-infrared (NIR) regions that are nearly unaffected by the ligand field. Especially, Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes are widely applied as luminescent materials for strong, easily detected emissions in the visible region, while Nd3+, Er3+, and Yb3+ complexes are studied in biological analysis because of their almost transparent NIR emissions in biological issues. Additionally, because of the large number of unpaired 4f electrons and magnetic anisotropy arising from the strong unquenched orbital angular momentum, lanthanide ions, especially heavy ones like Tb3+ and Dy3+, have recently been brought into the field of molecular magnetism. These molecules, such as SMMs and single-chain magnets (SCMs) with magnetic bistability, display slow relaxation of the magnetization at low temperature offering the opportunity to make quantum information devices.

elements.content: Nevertheless, the lanthanide complexes usually give weak luminescence due to the weak absorption coefficient, usually smaller than 10 M–1 cm–1 due to the spin- and parity-forbidden f–f transitions. In complexes, Ln3+ ions can exhibit variable coordination numbers (from 6 to 12) and flexible coordination fashions, so the predetermination and synthesis of the corresponding crystalline materials with excellent luminescent and magnetic properties are still a great challenge.

elements.content: To overcome this drawback, organic ligands with suitable chromophores and tailored coordinate sites have been employed as sensitizers and connectors to absorb light and transfer energy to the excited states of the central lanthanide ions, which is the so-called “antenna effect”. So far a number of organic molecules have been reported including β-diketonate, salen, and aromatic carboxylate ligands, which have been introduced to stabilize lanthanide ions and provide the antenna role for lanthanide luminescence. Among the present sensitizers, several quinoline-based chromophores attract notable attention for constructing luminescent complexes; for example, tris-8-(hydroxyquinoline) aluminum has been developed as an efficient electroluminescence material in organic light emitting diode (OLED) fabrication.

Among the present sensitizers, several quinoline-based chromophores attract notable attention for constructing luminescent complexes; for example, tris-8-(hydroxyquinoline) aluminum has been developed as an efficient electroluminescence material in organic light emitting diode (OLED) fabrication.

elements.content: Considering the intense affinity of Ln3+ ions for oxygen atoms, ligands with oxygenic coordination groups can be used as stable bridge or chelate ligands in the synthetic process of lanthanide complexes, which have been widely used to preclude the coordination of quenching species like solvent molecules to metal centers, therefore reducing the nonradiative decay processes. Meanwhile, the employment of carboxylate ligands as short bridging linkers can make contributions to efficient magnetic exchange between neighboring magnetic carriers, which has been proven to be a meaningful method to create lanthanide-based molecular magnet.

Meanwhile, the employment of carboxylate ligands as short bridging linkers can make contributions to efficient magnetic exchange between neighboring magnetic carriers, which has been proven to be a meaningful method to create lanthanide-based molecular magnet.

elements.content: As a consequence, use of the quinoline–carboxylic acid ligands incorporating carboxylate and quinoline groups, has remarkable advantages including strong coordination ability, a certain degree of rigidity, high energy transfer efficiency, and short exchange pathway between Ln3+ ions, which can be established as a popular approach to improving the luminous efficiency, magnetic exchange, and robustness for lanthanide complexes.

elements.content: Taking the above into account, we report the syntheses of a series of isostructural Ln3+ complexes based on 2-phenyl-4-quinolinecarboxylic acid (Hpqc) ligands: [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n (Ln = Sm (1), Eu (2), Gd (3), Tb (4), Dy (5), Ho (6), Er (7), Tm (8), Yb (9), or Lu (10)). The newly synthesized complexes have been elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffractometry (PXRD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy, UV–vis absorption spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis. The luminescent properties have been investigated, as well as the mechanism of energy transfer correlated to the singlet and triplet energy levels of the ligands. To our knowledge, it is the first example in which Hpqc was introduced to construct a lanthanide coordination polymer and as the sensitizer simultaneously. As an extension of our work, this infrequent rather complete series, in which all the complexes exhibit the exact same molecular structure and space group, offers a possibility to examine the effect of the lanthanide contraction (expected decrease in ionic radii of the lanthanide elements when increasing the atomic number throughout the series). In addition, the magnetic properties of 4–7 have been studied.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents were of analytical-grade quality, obtained from commercial sources, and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Thermal gravimetric (TG) analyses were performed in the temperature range of 30–1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 using a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected using a diffractometer (RIGAKU DMAX2500) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The UV–vis absorption spectra were collected on a Lambda-900 instrument from the Perkin–Elmer Corporation. Emission and excitation spectra were recorded on a Horiba Jobin–Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer analyzer. Quantum yields were performed on an Edinburgh Instruments model FLS920 spectrofluorometer equipped with both a continuous (450 W) xenon lamp and a pulse xenon lamp. Magnetic measurements for powder samples of 4–7 were carried out with a Quantum Design PPMS model 6000 magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The reagents and solvents were of analytical-grade quality, obtained from commercial sources, and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermal gravimetric (TG) analyses were performed in the temperature range of 30-1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 using a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected using a diffractometer (RIGAKU DMAX2500) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The UV-vis absorption spectra were collected on a Lambda-900 instrument from the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. Emission and excitation spectra were recorded on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer analyzer. Quantum yields were performed on an Edinburgh Instruments model FLS920 spectrofluorometer equipped with both a continuous (450 W) xenon lamp and a pulse xenon lamp. Magnetic measurements for powder samples of 4-7 were carried out with a Quantum Design PPMS model 6000 magnetometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 mmol) (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu), Hpqc (0.2 mmol), and ethanol (10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave under autogenous pressure at 80 °C for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, the yellow prism-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Complexes 1-10 

A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol) (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu), Hpqc (0.2 mmol), and ethanol (10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave under autogenous pressure at 80 °C for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, the yellow prism-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air.

Intensity data of 2–9 were collected on a Saturn 70 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω–2θ scan method at 293(2) K. All of the structures were solved with direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELX-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically in 2–9. The hydrogen atoms are located geometrically and treated as a riding model. The summary of crystallographic data and structural refinements for 2–9 are listed in Tables and . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 in the . CCDC 960742–960749 (2–9) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The hydrogen atoms are located geometrically and treated as a riding model. The summary of crystallographic data and structural refinements for 2-9 are listed in Tables  and . All the yellow crystalline compounds 1–10 have been synthesized by reaction of lanthanide nitrates and the Hpqc ligands in ethanol solution under solvothermal conditions. In order to obtain pure crystal phase products with high quality, we have adjusted the synthetic conditions and found that the molar ratio of Ln3+/Hpqc, reaction temperature, and pH of the reaction solution have a significant impact on the formation of these complexes The pure phases of 1–10 were observed with the molar ratio Ln3+/Hpqc = 1:2 at 80 °C. Deviation of the optimal conditions with different reactant molar ratios and higher temperature (over 100 °C) led to poor crystallinity of products with impurities and only clear solutions, respectively. When the organic bases like triethylamine, diethylamine, and 1,2-ethanediamine were added, colorless solutions were obtained, and then the crystalline Hpqc ligand appeared by slow evaporation. It is worth noting that despite all our efforts, we were not successful in gaining good samples of Sm3+ and Yb3+ complexes for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. However, X-ray powder diffraction and elemental analysis indicate that 1–10 are isostructural. In contrast, the isostructures of other light Ln3+ ions were not available, ascribed to the effect of lanthanide contraction hypothetically. According to that the charge-to-radius ratio of Ln3+ increase with atom numbers. In terms of the hard–soft acids–bases (HSAB) theory, the light Ln3+ ions are softer than the heavy ions, so La3+, Ce3+, Pr3+, and Nd3+ cations are more difficult to coordinate with the hard base of the O2– anion than other Ln3+ ions in this peculiar series. On the other hand, consistent with the ionic radii, light Ln3+ ions with larger size tend to form higher coordinated numbers than the eight-coordinated centers of this system, so this molecular model would not be capable of encapsulating all of the lanthanide ions, independently of their varying sizes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

All the yellow crystalline compounds 1-10 have been synthesized by reaction of lanthanide nitrates and the Hpqc ligands in ethanol solution under solvothermal conditions. In order to obtain pure crystal phase products with high quality, we have adjusted the synthetic conditions and found that the molar ratio of Ln3+/Hpqc, reaction temperature, and pH of the reaction solution have a significant impact on the formation of these complexes The pure phases of 1-10 were observed with the molar ratio Ln3+/Hpqc = 1:2 at 80 °C. Deviation of the optimal conditions with different reactant molar ratios and higher temperature (over 100 °C) led to poor crystallinity of products with impurities and only clear solutions, respectively. When the organic bases like triethylamine, diethylamine, and 1,2-ethanediamine were added, colorless solutions were obtained, and then the crystalline Hpqc ligand appeared by slow evaporation. It is worth noting that despite all our efforts, we were not successful in gaining good samples of Sm3+ and Yb3+ complexes for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. However, X-ray powder diffraction and elemental analysis indicate that 1-10 are isostructural. In contrast, the isostructures of other light Ln3+ ions were not available, ascribed to the effect of lanthanide contraction hypothetically. According to that the charge-to-radius ratio of Ln3+ increase with atom numbers. In terms of the hard-soft acids-bases (HSAB) theory, the light Ln3+ ions are softer than the heavy ions, so La3+, Ce3+, Pr3+, and Nd3+ cations are more difficult to coordinate with the hard base of the O2- anion than other Ln3+ ions in this peculiar series. On the other hand, consistent with the ionic radii, light Ln3+ ions with larger size tend to form higher coordinated numbers than the eight-coordinated centers of this system, so this molecular model would not be capable of encapsulating all of the lanthanide ions, independently of their varying sizes.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1–10 are isomorphic, so as a representative, the crystal structure of 2 is employed to be discussed in detail. Complex 2, crystallizing in the monoclinic system and space group P21/c, features a one-dimensional chain based on units of twisty rectangular plate constructed by Eu2(CO2)2. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one pqc– ligand, one Hpqc ligand protonated on the N atom of the pyridine ring, and two nitrate anions. The dihedral angle between the quinolyl and phenyl rings of pqc– and Hpqc are 27.9° and 12.9°, respectively. Each Eu3+ center is coordinated with eight oxygen atoms, including four carboxylic oxygen atoms from two pqc– and two Hpqc ligands in bridging bidentate model and four oxygen atoms from two terminal nitrates in chelating bidentate mode. As a result, the coordination geometry around the metal center can be best described as a distorted square antiprism (Figure b), in which the top quadrangle is made up of O1, O2, O6, and O8 while the bottom one is composed of O3, O4, O5, and O9. The Eu–O distances vary from 2.318(4) to 2.517(5) Å (Tables and ), in accordance with reported values in other europium–carboxylic oxygen donor complexes. Eu1 and its corresponding centrosymmetric generated atom Eu1B (symmetry code B = 2 – x, 1 – y, −z) are joined by two bidentate bridged carboxylic groups to form a binuclear twisty rectangular plate-like unit, with the separation of Eu···Eu being 5.3048(18) Å (Figure a). The binuclear unit grafted by four terminal chelating nitrates in the vertical direction of the plane is further connected by four adjacent ligands to form a one-dimensional ribbon structure along the [100] direction (Figure b). It is worth nothing that π···π interactions and hydrogen bonding play a critical role to stabilize the structure. The pyridyl rings of ligands on both sides of the chain are almost parallel within nearby ones; thus the intrachain π···π interactions in face-to-face mode take place (between rings C2–C3–C8–N1–C10–C9 and C18A–C19A–C24A–N2A–C26A–C25A, symmetry code A = 1 – x, 1 – y, −z), with the intercentroid distances being 3.544 Å (Figure b). It is interesting that the N atom of Hqpc is not coordinated, so the moieties are extended into a 3D metal–organic supramolecular framework through the N–H···O hydrogen bonding between the nitrates and the nitrogen atoms in the Hpqc (N2–HN2···O7C = 3.039 Å, symmetry code C = x, 1/2 – y, z – 1/2) and the interchain π···π interactions of pyridyl and the phenyl rings of ligands among four neighboring chains (between rings of C27–C32 and C2D–C3D–C8D–N1D–C10D–C9D and between rings of C11D–C16D and C18–C19–C24–N2–C26–C25, respectively, symmetry code D = 1 – x, y – 1/2, −z – 1/2) with intercentroid distances being 3.773 and 3.633 Å, respectively (Figure c,d). The related data about hydrogen bonds for 2–9 are described in Table S2 in the . The structure of 2 is different from other metal–Hpqc complexes reported in literature and is the first example of a 1D chain based on Hpqc.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description of [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc) (NO3)2] n  (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, or Yb)

X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1-10 are isomorphic, so as a representative, the crystal structure of 2 is employed to be discussed in detail. Complex 2, crystallizing in the monoclinic system and space group P21/c, features a one-dimensional chain based on units of twisty rectangular plate constructed by Eu2(CO2)2. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one pqc- ligand, one Hpqc ligand protonated on the N atom of the pyridine ring, and two nitrate anions. The dihedral angle between the quinolyl and phenyl rings of pqc- and Hpqc are 27.9° and 12.9°, respectively. Each Eu3+ center is coordinated with eight oxygen atoms, including four carboxylic oxygen atoms from two pqc- and two Hpqc ligands in bridging bidentate model and four oxygen atoms from two terminal nitrates in chelating bidentate mode. As a result, the coordination geometry around the metal center can be best described as a distorted square antiprism (Figure b), in which the top quadrangle is made up of O1, O2, O6, and O8 while the bottom one is composed of O3, O4, O5, and O9. The Eu-O distances vary from 2.318(4) to 2.517(5) Å (Tables  and ), in accordance with reported values in other europium-carboxylic oxygen donor complexes. Eu1 and its corresponding centrosymmetric generated atom Eu1B (symmetry code B = 2 - x, 1 - y, -z) are joined by two bidentate bridged carboxylic groups to form a binuclear twisty rectangular plate-like unit, with the separation of Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu being 5.3048(18) Å (Figure a). The binuclear unit grafted by four terminal chelating nitrates in the vertical direction of the plane is further connected by four adjacent ligands to form a one-dimensional ribbon structure along the [100] direction (Figure b). It is worth nothing that π⋅⋅⋅π interactions and hydrogen bonding play a critical role to stabilize the structure. The pyridyl rings of ligands on both sides of the chain are almost parallel within nearby ones; thus the intrachain π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in face-to-face mode take place (between rings C2-C3-C8-N1-C10-C9 and C18A-C19A-C24A-N2A-C26A-C25A, symmetry code A = 1 - x, 1 - y, -z), with the intercentroid distances being 3.544 Å (Figure b). It is interesting that the N atom of Hqpc is not coordinated, so the moieties are extended into a 3D metal-organic supramolecular framework through the N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding between the nitrates and the nitrogen atoms in the Hpqc (N2-HN2⋅⋅⋅O7C = 3.039 Å, symmetry code C = x, 1/2 - y, z - 1/2) and the interchain π⋅⋅⋅π interactions of pyridyl and the phenyl rings of ligands among four neighboring chains (between rings of C27-C32 and C2D-C3D-C8D-N1D-C10D-C9D and between rings of C11D-C16D and C18-C19-C24-N2-C26-C25, respectively, symmetry code D = 1 - x, y - 1/2, -z - 1/2) with intercentroid distances being 3.773 and 3.633 Å, respectively (Figure c,d). The related data about hydrogen bonds for 2-9 are described in Table S2 in the . elements.content: The thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on 1–10 to investigate their thermal stabilities with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 in the temperature range of 30–1000 °C under N2 atmosphere. TGA curves of isomorphous 1–10 have similar profiles, exhibiting one main weight loss step until the decomposition of the framework. Herein, 2 is used as representative illustrated in Figure , and the thermogravimetric analyses of other complexes are provided as Figure S1 in the . The TGA curve of 2 indicates the thermal stability up to 278 °C, and then the weight loss of 16.8% in the range of 278 to 425 °C is attributed to the loss of two coordinated nitrate anions (calcd 16.4%), and after that the framework decomposes gradually.

elements.content: The crystalline products of 1–10 have been characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature (Figure S2, ). The observed XRD patterns are in good agreement with the results simulated from the single-crystal data, indicating the high purity of the synthesized samples. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra of the free ligand and those of corresponding Ln3+ complexes are measured in dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (c = 1 × 10–5 M) and are displayed in Figure . The ligand Hpqc displays two broad bands at 268 and 315 nm in the UV region, attributed to singlet–singlet n → π* and π → π* transitions of the aromatic rings. Compared with the ligand, the maximum absorption peaks at long wavelength bands are red-shifted to about 330 nm for 1–10, which is attributed to the perturbation induced by the coordination of the Ln3+ ion. The absorption profile of each complex is identical in the range of 260–400 nm, indicating that the coordination of Ln3+ ions does not significantly influence the energy of the singlet states of the Hpqc ligand.

elements.content: Like the well-known luminescence features of lanthanide ions, the complexes reported in this article possess interesting luminescent properties, showing the typical linear lanthanide-based and enhanced broad ligand emissions both in the visible and in the near-infrared regions. Although weak for 4 (Tb), 6 (Ho), and 8 (Tm), emission is reasonably strong for 1 (Sm), 5 (Dy), 7 (Er), and 9 (Yb) and strong enough to be seen by the naked eye under illumination with a standard laboratory UV-lamp for 2 (Eu) and 10 (Lu).
elements.clean_text:
Visible Luminescent Properties

Like the well-known luminescence features of lanthanide ions, the complexes reported in this article possess interesting luminescent properties, showing the typical linear lanthanide-based and enhanced broad ligand emissions both in the visible and in the near-infrared regions. Although weak for 4 (Tb), 6 (Ho), and 8 (Tm), emission is reasonably strong for 1 (Sm), 5 (Dy), 7 (Er), and 9 (Yb) and strong enough to be seen by the naked eye under illumination with a standard laboratory UV-lamp for 2 (Eu) and 10 (Lu).

elements.content: The luminescent properties of ligand and lanthanide complexes in the solid-state were investigated at room temperature. Under excitation at 365 nm for Hpqc, the pure ligand presents a blue-green emission with the peak at 496 nm (Figure S3, ). The excitation spectrum of 1 recorded by monitoring the characteristic 642 nm emission band of Sm3+ ion shows a dominated broad band between 250 and 400 nm, which can be assigned to the n → π* and π → π* transitions of the coordinated ligand from the comparison of the absorption spectra. The emission spectrum of 1 exhibits the typical emission bands of the Sm3+ ion, upon excitation of 395 nm, centered at 560, 597, 642, and 702 nm, which are assigned to the transitions of 4G5/2 to 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, and 11/2). Besides intense sharp peaks of the Sm3+ ion, a broad emission band centered at 494 nm is also detected, which results from the ligand fluorescence (Figure a). The excitation and emission spectra of 4 are similar to those of 1 shown in Figure b, where f–f transitions of the Tb3+ ion with ligand-centered emission are observed. Upon excitation at 397 nm, three weak characteristic luminescent bands of Tb3+ ions at 493 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 546 nm (5D4 → 7F5), and 623 nm (5D4 → 7F3) appear, while the relatively manifest broad peaks (475–525 nm) corresponding to self-emission of the Hpqc ligand overlap the peak of 5D4 → 7F6 transition. Therefore, 1 and 4 exhibit low PL intensity, signifying that efficiency of energy transfer from Hpqc ligands to Sm3+ and Tb3+ ions is not ideal.

elements.content: When the Hpqc ligand is introduced to sensitize the Eu3+ ion, the emission spectrum of 2 exhibits the typical sharp characteristic emission bands, upon excitation at 397 nm, centered at 579, 591, 613, 650, and 696 nm (Figure a), which are assigned to the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0–4) transitions, respectively. No broad emission band resulting from the ligand is observed, which demonstrates that the ligand transfers the absorbed energy effectively to the emitting levels of the Eu3+ center. The most intense emission at 613 nm is attributed to the 5D0 → 7F2 (electric-dipole) transition, which is hypersensitive to the coordination environment of the Eu3+ ion and implies a red emission light. The inset in the upper left shows the photographs for the tablet of 2 and its brilliant emission color under UV-light excitation (365 nm). The medium-strong emission band at 590 nm corresponds to the 5D0 → 7F1 (magnetic dipole) transition, which is fairly insensitive to the environment of the Eu3+ ion. The intensity ratio of 5.5 for I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) indicates that the coordination environment of the Eu3+ ions in 2 is at a low symmetry devoid of an inversion center. The emission spectrum is partially magnified in Figure a in order to study the details of the 5D0 → 7F1 and 7F2 transitions. We can see that ligand splits 7F1 and 7F2 levels into three and four Stark items (the peaks at 519 and 613 nm can be decomposed by three and four Gaussian bands), respectively, and the 5D0 → 7F0 transition just exhibits a single peak. Therefore, we can conclude that Eu3+ ions are at a low symmetry site similar to C 2v chemical environments in agreement with the result of X-ray crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: Different from those of 1, 2, and 4, no characteristic peaks of Dy3+, Ho3+, and Tm3+ for 5, 6, and 8 are observed at room temperature except for broad emission bands at 519, 510, and 506 nm, respectively, originating from an intraligand π → π* transition of ligands. It is red-shifted from 10–23 nm in comparison to the ligand because of rigidity and conjugation of the ligand changed after formation of the lanthanide coordination polymers (Figure S4, ). So we can draw a conclusion that the triplet state energy level of the ligand mismatches the excited state energy levels of these lanthanide ions. Interestingly, it is obviously that a broad green emission band at 498 nm was observed for 10 assigned to ligand centered fluorescence on excitation at 397 nm (Figure b). The full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of 10 is 67 nm. It is markedly narrower than those of other Lu3+ complexes. The inset in the upper-left shows the photographs for the tablet of 10 and its strong emission color under UV-light excitation (365 nm). It is well-known that among the lanthanide elements, Lu3+ ion has a filled 4f shell; thus no f–f transitions happen and consequently no emission in the visible range of the spectrum is observed. However, when Lu3+ ion coordinates with an organic ligand to form a metal–organic complex, it can sensitize and enhance the emission of organic chromophores. In consideration of the wide application of AlQ3 (Q = 8-hydroxyquinoline) in the field of photoluminescence and electroluminescence materials, the ligand-emission lanthanide complexes deserve further study.

elements.content: The luminescence spectra of the Er3+ and Yb3+ complexes in the solid-state have been investigated upon excitation at 397 nm, displaying typical emissions in the NIR region. The emission spectrum of 7 (Figure a) presents a single band at 1536 nm, assigned to the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition of the Er3+ ion. The emission spectrum of 9 (Figure b) exhibits a NIR emission around 1026 nm, which can be assigned to the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition of Yb3+ ion. Strikingly, the emission of the Yb3+ ion in 9 is not a single sharp transition, but well-split peaks are observed, where it appears as the other weak band centered at 982 nm. A similar splitting has been reported previously and is attributed to the crystal field or stark splitting. The absence of the ligand-centered luminescence in the emission spectra of 7 and 9 indicate that the ligand-to-metal energy transfer is efficient.

Near-Infrared Luminescent Properties

The luminescence spectra of the Er3+ and Yb3+ complexes in the solid-state have been investigated upon excitation at 397 nm, displaying typical emissions in the NIR region. The emission spectrum of 7 (Figure a) presents a single band at 1536 nm, assigned to the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition of the Er3+ ion. The emission spectrum of 9 (Figure b) exhibits a NIR emission around 1026 nm, which can be assigned to the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition of Yb3+ ion. Strikingly, the emission of the Yb3+ ion in 9 is not a single sharp transition, but well-split peaks are observed, where it appears as the other weak band centered at 982 nm. A similar splitting has been reported previously and is attributed to the crystal field or stark splitting. The absence of the ligand-centered luminescence in the emission spectra of 7 and 9 indicate that the ligand-to-metal energy transfer is efficient.

elements.content: The commonly accepted energy transfer mechanism in lanthanide complexes is that proposed by Crosby and Whan. The metal centered luminescence of those complexes is explained by the ligand-to-metal energy transfer from the lowest triplet level of ligand to an excited state of lanthanide ion through a nonradiative transition. In order to elucidate the energy transfer process of [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n in this paper, the energy levels of the relevant singlet and triplet excited states of Hpqc should be estimated. The single energy level of Hpqc (1ππ*) is estimated by referring to its upper wavelength absorbance edge of UV–vis absorption spectrum (Figure ), which is about 27174 cm–1 (368 nm). Considering the difficulty in obtaining the phosphorescence spectrum of ligand, the triplet energy level of Hpqc can be estimated by referring to the lower wavelength emission edge of the phosphorescence spectrum of corresponding Gd3+ complex. Because the triplet state energy level of the ligand is much lower than the lowest excited level of Gd3+ (6P7/2 → 8S7/2) located at 32150 cm–1, it will not be significantly affected by the Gd3+ ion. As illustrated in Figure S5 in the , the triplet energy level of Hpqc (3ππ*) is calculated to be about 19557 cm–1 (512 nm). So the energy gap between singlet and triplet states of Hpqc is 7617 cm–1, larger than 5000 cm–1, implying that the intersystem crossing process is effective according to Reinhoudt’s empirical rule.
elements.clean_text:
Intramolecular Energy Transfer between Ligand and Ln3+ Ions

The commonly accepted energy transfer mechanism in lanthanide complexes is that proposed by Crosby and Whan. The metal centered luminescence of those complexes is explained by the ligand-to-metal energy transfer from the lowest triplet level of ligand to an excited state of lanthanide ion through a nonradiative transition. In order to elucidate the energy transfer process of [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n  in this paper, the energy levels of the relevant singlet and triplet excited states of Hpqc should be estimated. The single energy level of Hpqc (1ππ*) is estimated by referring to its upper wavelength absorbance edge of UV-vis absorption spectrum (Figure ), which is about 27174 cm-1 (368 nm). Considering the difficulty in obtaining the phosphorescence spectrum of ligand, the triplet energy level of Hpqc can be estimated by referring to the lower wavelength emission edge of the phosphorescence spectrum of corresponding Gd3+ complex. Because the triplet state energy level of the ligand is much lower than the lowest excited level of Gd3+ (6P7/2 → 8S7/2) located at 32150 cm-1, it will not be significantly affected by the Gd3+ ion. As illustrated in Figure S5 in the , the triplet energy level of Hpqc (3ππ*) is calculated to be about 19557 cm-1 (512 nm). So the energy gap between singlet and triplet states of Hpqc is 7617 cm-1, larger than 5000 cm-1, implying that the intersystem crossing process is effective according to Reinhoudt's empirical rule.

elements.content: According to Dexter’s theory, the energy difference ΔE, between ligand and excited level of Ln3+ is an important exponent to affect energy transition. Whether the energy gap is too large or too small, the energy transfer rate from ligand to Ln3+ will decrease, resulting in low intensity of the corresponding Ln3+ luminescence. It can be seen from Figure that the triplet energy level of the Hpqc ligand (19557 cm–1) lies above the resonant level of Eu3+ (5D0 = 17277 cm–1) and Sm3+ (4G5/2 = 17800 cm–1) allowing an efficient ligand-to-metal energy transfer. In contrast to 1 (Sm) and 2 (Eu), only weak lanthanide-based luminescence is observed for 4 (Tb) because of the higher excited energy state and close energy gap of the triplet state in the Hpqc sensitizer and Tb3+ (5D4 = 20500 cm–1, ΔE = 943 cm–1) resulting in thermally promoted back-transfer of energy. The overall luminescence quantum yields (Φ) for 1 and 2 are 0.4% and 7.3%, respectively. The relative low quantum yield for 1 can be explained by the susceptibility of the 4G5/2 state of Sm3+ for nonradiative vibrational relaxation by C–H and N–H oscillators in the surrounding ligand. The energy gap between this triplet level and the emission levels of Dy3+, Ho3+ and Tm3+ is too large, leading to nonradiative relaxation channeling away the energy rather than transferring to the Ln3+ ion. Our results show that Hpqc is a good sensitizer for near-infrared emitting lanthanide complexes in agreement with the conclusion that a relatively lower-lying triplet state is suited to efficiently transfer energy to the 4I15/2 and 2F5/2 luminescent level of Er3+ and Yb3+, respectively. Significantly, the realization of ligands that can match a series of lanthanide ions emitting both in visible and in near-infrared regions through a single sensitizer is now an attractive target in terms of multiplexed signal output for assays. The well-positioned triplet energy level of the Hpqc ligand allows sensitization of a range of luminescent states for Ln3+ ions.
elements.clean_text: According to Dexter's theory, the energy difference ΔE, between ligand and excited level of Ln3+ is an important exponent to affect energy transition. Whether the energy gap is too large or too small, the energy transfer rate from ligand to Ln3+ will decrease, resulting in low intensity of the corresponding Ln3+ luminescence. It can be seen from Figure  that the triplet energy level of the Hpqc ligand (19557 cm-1) lies above the resonant level of Eu3+ (5D0 = 17277 cm-1) and Sm3+ (4G5/2 = 17800 cm-1) allowing an efficient ligand-to-metal energy transfer. In contrast to 1 (Sm) and 2 (Eu), only weak lanthanide-based luminescence is observed for 4 (Tb) because of the higher excited energy state and close energy gap of the triplet state in the Hpqc sensitizer and Tb3+ (5D4 = 20500 cm-1, ΔE = 943 cm-1) resulting in thermally promoted back-transfer of energy. The overall luminescence quantum yields (Φ) for 1 and 2 are 0.4% and 7.3%, respectively. The relative low quantum yield for 1 can be explained by the susceptibility of the 4G5/2 state of Sm3+ for nonradiative vibrational relaxation by C-H and N-H oscillators in the surrounding ligand. The energy gap between this triplet level and the emission levels of Dy3+, Ho3+ and Tm3+ is too large, leading to nonradiative relaxation channeling away the energy rather than transferring to the Ln3+ ion. Our results show that Hpqc is a good sensitizer for near-infrared emitting lanthanide complexes in agreement with the conclusion that a relatively lower-lying triplet state is suited to efficiently transfer energy to the 4I15/2 and 2F5/2 luminescent level of Er3+ and Yb3+, respectively. Significantly, the realization of ligands that can match a series of lanthanide ions emitting both in visible and in near-infrared regions through a single sensitizer is now an attractive target in terms of multiplexed signal output for assays. The well-positioned triplet energy level of the Hpqc ligand allows sensitization of a range of luminescent states for Ln3+ ions.

elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 4–7 were measured on powder samples in an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe at temperatures between 2 and 300 K, and the χM T (χM being the molar magnetic susceptibility) and 1/χM vs T are shown in Figure a,b. For 4, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility reveals that at room temperature, the χM T value of 11.58 cm3 K mol–1 is close to the calculated value of 11.82 cm3 K mol–1 for one magnetically isolated Tb3+ ion (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2). The value of χM T is temperature independent to some degree until 230 K. Then, on further cooling, an abrupt increase appears and reaches a spread maximum of 17.36 cm3 K mol–1 at T = 15.93 K, which indicates ferromagnetic interaction within the chain. After that a sudden decrease in χM T is observed, to the value of 12.14 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Between 16 and 300 K, the linear fit of 1/χM vs. T obeys the Curie–Weiss law 1/χM = (T – θ)/C M, with C M = 11.20 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 14.05 K. For 5, at 300 K, χM T per Dy3+ ion is 14.33 cm3 K mol–1, which is in agreement with the calculated value of 14.15 cm3 K mol–1 (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6H15/2, g = 4/3,). Upon cooling, χM T increases gradually at 5 K and finally increases rapidly on further cooling to a maximum value of 20.61 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, demonstrating ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions in the carboxylate-bridged chain. Between 2 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with C M = 14.38 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 5.36 K. The positive value of θ further confirms the existence of ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions.

The value of χM T is temperature independent to some degree until 230 K. Then, on further cooling, an abrupt increase appears and reaches a spread maximum of 17.36 cm3 K mol-1 at T = 15.93 K, which indicates ferromagnetic interaction within the chain. After that a sudden decrease in χM T is observed, to the value of 12.14 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. Between 16 and 300 K, the linear fit of 1/χM vs. T obeys the Curie-Weiss law 1/χM = (T - θ)/C M, with C M = 11.20 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 14.05 K. For 5, at 300 K, χM T per Dy3+ ion is 14.33 cm3 K mol-1, which is in agreement with the calculated value of 14.15 cm3 K mol-1 (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6H15/2, g = 4/3,). Upon cooling, χM T increases gradually at 5 K and finally increases rapidly on further cooling to a maximum value of 20.61 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, demonstrating ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions in the carboxylate-bridged chain. Between 2 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie-Weiss law with C M = 14.38 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 5.36 K. elements.content: For 6, at room temperature, the χM T value is 13.56 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly lower than the theoretical value of 14.07 cm3 K mol–1 expected for one Ho3+ ion (S = 2, L = 6, 5I8, g = 5/4). Upon cooling, the χM T value increases gradually to 15.27 cm3 K mol–1 at 42 K, which may indicate the presence of weak ferromagnetic coupling between Ho3+ ions. With further cooling, the χM T value decreases quickly to 4.05 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Between 42 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with C M = 13.10 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 7.35 K. For 7, at room temperature, the χM T value of 11.18 cm3 K mol–1 is consistent with the value of 11.48 cm3 K mol–1 for noninteracting Er3+ ion (S = 3/2, L = 6, 4I15/2, g = 6/5). As the temperature is lowered, the χM T value slowly decreases to 10.70 cm3 K mol–1 at 48 K. With further cooling, the χM T value decreases rapidly to 7.70 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Between 2 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law, with C M = 11.02 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −2.13K.

elements.content: For 4, 6, and 7, a sudden decrease in the χM T is observed. This feature can be generally attributed to one or a combination of the following three phenomena: (1) the thermal depopulation of the Stark sublevels; (2) weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ln3+ ions within the chain; (3) the significant magnetic anisotropy of Ln3+ ions. On account of the larger spin–orbit coupling and magnetic anisotropy of Er3+, it is difficult to decide whether this small negative Weiss temperature indicates antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Er3+ ions of 7. It is notable that the χM T value remains consistent at high temperature, which indicates the competition balance between ferromagnetic interaction and thermal depopulation of Stark sublevels. Namely, ferromagnetic interactions exist in 7. The magnetic susceptibility data of 5 suggests that ferromagnetic interactions dominate. The linear variation of ln(χM T) versus T –1 observed indicates a strong Ising-like chain, obeying an exponential behavior, χM T ∝ e2J/(kT), where J is the exchange energy between nearest-neighbors (, Figure S6).

On account of the larger spin-orbit coupling and magnetic anisotropy of Er3+, it is difficult to decide whether this small negative Weiss temperature indicates antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Er3+ ions of 7. It is notable that the χM T value remains consistent at high temperature, which indicates the competition balance between ferromagnetic interaction and thermal depopulation of Stark sublevels. Namely, ferromagnetic interactions exist in 7. The magnetic susceptibility data of 5 suggests that ferromagnetic interactions dominate. The linear variation of ln(χM T) versus T -1 observed indicates a strong Ising-like chain, obeying an exponential behavior, χM T ∝ e2J/(kT), where J is the exchange energy between nearest-neighbors (, Figure S6).

elements.content: To examine the dynamics of the magnetization, alternating current (ac) susceptibility has been measured on complexes 4–7 at low temperature under a zero dc field in an oscillating ac field of 3 Oe with frequencies ranging between 611 and 5011 Hz. For 4, 6, and 7, the signals of the temperature dependence, both in-phase (χM′) and out-of-phase (χM″), do not display frequency-dependence phenomenon, which excludes the possibility of single molecular magnet for them (Figure S7–S9, ). Interestingly, 5 (Dy) shows clear frequency dependence for in-phase and out-of-phase curves below 12 K to give good peak shapes, which is positive proof for slow relaxation and SMM behavior (Figure ).

elements.content: The peaks of out-of-phase signals are visible and the relaxation time (τ) data obtained from the ac data follow the Arrhenius law τ = τ0 exp(Δ/(k B T)). By plotting ln τ versus 1/T, we obtain the values for the energy barrier, Δ/k B = 48.86 K, and the pre-exponential factor, τ0 = 6.88 × 10–7 s (Figure ). The obtained results of Δ/k B and τ0 are consistent with a superparamagnetic-like character of the relaxation dynamics and comparable to those of reported SMMs. Further, the shift of the peak temperature (T P) of χM″ is calculated by a parameter Φ = (ΔT P/T P)/Δ(log f), where f is the frequency. The value of 0.28 for 5 was obtained, which excludes the possibility of a spin glass (0.01 < Φ < 0.08). Taking the crystal structure into account, 4–7 are isostructural; however, only 5 exhibits the slow magnetic relaxation property, which is not detected in other corresponding isomorphous complexes. Thus, this magnetic slow relaxation behavior can be attributed to the anisotropy of Dy3+ ions.

elements.content: A family of isotypical rare earth complexes, [Ln(Hpqc)hpqc(NO3)2] n , have been synthesized and characterized in this work. The analysis of the structural data is available for a direct experimental evaluation of lanthanide contraction, which is well-known as the greater than expected decrease in ionic radii of the elements in the lanthanide series. These isostructural complexes ensure the nature of change along the series, thus facilitating the research on the phenomenon due to the following reasons: (1) the series extends over the last half of continuous lanthanide series (from Eu to Yb), (2) the quality of the diffractometric data allows an exact investigation on the fitting curves, and (3) the presence of two types of Ln–O bonds in the coordination sphere of the lanthanide could give a comprehensive scrutiny on contraction effect.
elements.clean_text:
Analysis of Lanthanide Contraction Effect

A family of isotypical rare earth complexes, [Ln(Hpqc)hpqc(NO3)2] n , have been synthesized and characterized in this work. The analysis of the structural data is available for a direct experimental evaluation of lanthanide contraction, which is well-known as the greater than expected decrease in ionic radii of the elements in the lanthanide series. These isostructural complexes ensure the nature of change along the series, thus facilitating the research on the phenomenon due to the following reasons: (1) the series extends over the last half of continuous lanthanide series (from Eu to Yb), (2) the quality of the diffractometric data allows an exact investigation on the fitting curves, and (3) the presence of two types of Ln-O bonds in the coordination sphere of the lanthanide could give a comprehensive scrutiny on contraction effect.

elements.content: The distances between Ln centers and O atoms from ligands and nitrate anions for 2 to 9 are listed in Tables and , respectively. It is apparent that the lanthanide contraction effect is reflected in the decreasing of the Ln–O bond lengths with increasing atomic numbers. In fact, the general trend for Ln–O distances holds the monotonic shrinking throughout all the complexes (the two typical average distances of Ln–O bond decrease around Eu to Yb). From previous reports, it was shown the contraction of Ln3+ ionic radii and Ln–O bond lengths to some extent follow a quadratic decay as a function of the number n of f electrons. Later, the lanthanide contraction owing to incomplete shielding of the (5s, 5p) electrons from the increased nuclear charge by the 4f electrons was derived theoretically from Slater’s model, which utilized a screening constant s to express the shielding of the nuclear charge Z by inner electron shells. Furthermore, the sum of total bond lengths (∑d Ln–O) around the trivalent metal cation is regarded as the more regular and ideal parameter for quadratic behavior across the entire series, because the contraction in the individual Ln–O bond lengths deviates from the expected quadratic decrease due to the different force field of ligands sometimes. Considering the overall contribution of Ln–O bonds and Slater’s model for the lanthanide contraction yields eq , where S(n) is the sum over all m Ln–O bond lengths, S L is the sum of all radii of the ligating atoms (assumed to be constant), m is the number of coordination for homogeneous ligand, r 0 and Z 0 * are the ionic radius and effective nuclear charge of La3+, respectively, and k is the screening constant for one 4f electron. S ( n ) = S L + m r 0 − [ m r 0 ( 1 − k ) / Z 0 * ] n + [ m r 0 ( 1 − k ) 2 / ( Z 0 * ) 2 ] n 2 = A 0 + A 1 n + A 2 n 2

elements.content: When dealing with the Ln–O distances in this series, we divide the Ln–O bonds into Ln–O(L) (ligand) part and Ln–O(N) (nitrate anion) part, considering the ensemble of Ln–O distances (∑d Ln–O) that involves only homogeneous species at one time. Figure shows the variation with n of the sums of ∑d Ln–O(L) and ∑d Ln–O(N) (m = 4 for both species) for 2–9. The data could be fit satisfactorily to a quadratic polynomial equation with a weighting factor of σ2. According to parameters of eq , the screening constant can be determined by k = 1 + Z 0 * A 2/A 1 with a value for Z 0 * = 15.42, which is found to be equal to 0.57 and 0.76 for ∑d Ln–O(L) and ∑d Ln–O(N), respectively. These results agree with the commonly accepted value of k = 0.69 and are close to the previously reported number for another series of Ln complexes (k = 0.57, 0.65, and 0.64). The difference in the values of the 4f electron screening constant obtained from Ln–O bonds of coordinated ligands and nitrate ions could be ascribed to different effects of crystal field and bonding strength on the capacity of the electrons to shield the nuclear charge. It is interesting to note that the decrease of Ln–Ln distances found in 2–9 also follows the lanthanide contraction (, Table S3).

Figure  shows the variation with n of the sums of ∑d Ln-O(L) and ∑d Ln-O(N) (m = 4 for both species) for 2-9. The data could be fit satisfactorily to a quadratic polynomial equation with a weighting factor of σ2. According to parameters of eq , the screening constant can be determined by k = 1 + Z 0 * A 2/A 1 with a value for Z 0 * = 15.42, which is found to be equal to 0.57 and 0.76 for ∑d Ln-O(L) and ∑d Ln-O(N), respectively. These results agree with the commonly accepted value of k = 0.69 and are close to the previously reported number for another series of Ln complexes (k = 0.57, 0.65, and 0.64). The difference in the values of the 4f electron screening constant obtained from Ln-O bonds of coordinated ligands and nitrate ions could be ascribed to different effects of crystal field and bonding strength on the capacity of the electrons to shield the nuclear charge. It is interesting to note that the decrease of Ln-Ln distances found in 2-9 also follows the lanthanide contraction (, Table S3).

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized 10 novel luminescent lanthanide coordination complexes [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n by solvothermal reaction at low temperature. The series of complexes with isostructures form an interesting 3D supramolecular framework built of Ln–Hpqc infinite chains through π···π stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions. This isostructurally characterized series of lanthanide complexes has been employed for research of the lanthanide contraction. The quadratic decay has been found by analyzing the sum of Ln–O distances belonging to the Hpqc ligands and nitrates, respectively, evaluated with Slater’s model of the atomic radii. The detailed luminescent properties of 1–10 in the solid state are investigated at room temperature. It is found that upon UV excitation, the ligand sensitizes the characteristic luminescences of the Ln3+ ions emitting in the visible region for Sm3+, Eu3+, and Tb3+ complexes, as well as in the near-infrared (NIR) region for Er3+ and Yb3+ complexes. Furthermore, the Dy3+, Ho3+, Tm3+, and Lu3+ complexes exhibit bright green luminescence in the solid-state because of the intraligand transition (π–π*). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first series of 2-phenyl-4-quinolinecarboxylic acid based lanthanide coordination complexes and corresponding Eu3+, Lu3+, and Yb3+ complexes with intense red, green, and NIR luminescence, respectively, may be potential fluorescence materials in many photonic devices. Remarkably, because the energy level of the triplet state of the ligand determined from the phosphorescent spectrum of the Gd3+ complex is suited, the realization of Hpqc sensitizing a series of lanthanide ions that emit in both the visible and near-infrared regions will lead to additional exploration of potential application for multiplex assays. In addition, the magnetic studies reveal that ferromagnetic interactions appear in 4–7, and especially, the dysprosium complex with Ising-like chain exhibiting slow relaxation could be a potential candidate for single-molecule magnets (SMMs).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized 10 novel luminescent lanthanide coordination complexes [Ln(pqc)(Hpqc)(NO3)2] n  by solvothermal reaction at low temperature. The series of complexes with isostructures form an interesting 3D supramolecular framework built of Ln-Hpqc infinite chains through π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions. This isostructurally characterized series of lanthanide complexes has been employed for research of the lanthanide contraction. The quadratic decay has been found by analyzing the sum of Ln-O distances belonging to the Hpqc ligands and nitrates, respectively, evaluated with Slater's model of the atomic radii. The detailed luminescent properties of 1-10 in the solid state are investigated at room temperature. It is found that upon UV excitation, the ligand sensitizes the characteristic luminescences of the Ln3+ ions emitting in the visible region for Sm3+, Eu3+, and Tb3+ complexes, as well as in the near-infrared (NIR) region for Er3+ and Yb3+ complexes. Furthermore, the Dy3+, Ho3+, Tm3+, and Lu3+ complexes exhibit bright green luminescence in the solid-state because of the intraligand transition (π-π*). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first series of 2-phenyl-4-quinolinecarboxylic acid based lanthanide coordination complexes and corresponding Eu3+, Lu3+, and Yb3+ complexes with intense red, green, and NIR luminescence, respectively, may be potential fluorescence materials in many photonic devices. Remarkably, because the energy level of the triplet state of the ligand determined from the phosphorescent spectrum of the Gd3+ complex is suited, the realization of Hpqc sensitizing a series of lanthanide ions that emit in both the visible and near-infrared regions will lead to additional exploration of potential application for multiplex assays. In addition, the magnetic studies reveal that ferromagnetic interactions appear in 4-7, and especially, the dysprosium complex with Ising-like chain exhibiting slow relaxation could be a potential candidate for single-molecule magnets (SMMs).

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 mmol) (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu), Hpqc (0.2 mmol), and ethanol (10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave under autogenous pressure at 80 °C for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, the yellow prism-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air.

Syntheses of Complexes 1-10 

A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol) (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu), Hpqc (0.2 mmol), and ethanol (10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave under autogenous pressure at 80 °C for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, the yellow prism-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air.

Thermogravimetric Analysis and Powder X-ray Diffraction

The thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on 1–10 to investigate their thermal stabilities with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 in the temperature range of 30–1000 °C under N2 atmosphere. TGA curves of isomorphous 1–10 have similar profiles, exhibiting one main weight loss step until the decomposition of the framework. Herein, 2 is used as representative illustrated in Figure , and the thermogravimetric analyses of other complexes are provided as Figure S1 in the . The TGA curve of 2 indicates the thermal stability up to 278 °C, and then the weight loss of 16.8% in the range of 278 to 425 °C is attributed to the loss of two coordinated nitrate anions (calcd 16.4%), and after that the framework decomposes gradually.

Visible Luminescent Properties

Like the well-known luminescence features of lanthanide ions, the complexes reported in this article possess interesting luminescent properties, showing the typical linear lanthanide-based and enhanced broad ligand emissions both in the visible and in the near-infrared regions. Although weak for 4 (Tb), 6 (Ho), and 8 (Tm), emission is reasonably strong for 1 (Sm), 5 (Dy), 7 (Er), and 9 (Yb) and strong enough to be seen by the naked eye under illumination with a standard laboratory UV-lamp for 2 (Eu) and 10 (Lu).

Near-Infrared Luminescent Properties

The luminescence spectra of the Er3+ and Yb3+ complexes in the solid-state have been investigated upon excitation at 397 nm, displaying typical emissions in the NIR region. The emission spectrum of 7 (Figure a) presents a single band at 1536 nm, assigned to the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition of the Er3+ ion. The emission spectrum of 9 (Figure b) exhibits a NIR emission around 1026 nm, which can be assigned to the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition of Yb3+ ion. Strikingly, the emission of the Yb3+ ion in 9 is not a single sharp transition, but well-split peaks are observed, where it appears as the other weak band centered at 982 nm. A similar splitting has been reported previously and is attributed to the crystal field or stark splitting. The absence of the ligand-centered luminescence in the emission spectra of 7 and 9 indicate that the ligand-to-metal energy transfer is efficient.

cln_elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 4–7 were measured on powder samples in an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe at temperatures between 2 and 300 K, and the χM T (χM being the molar magnetic susceptibility) and 1/χM vs T are shown in Figure a,b. For 4, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility reveals that at room temperature, the χM T value of 11.58 cm3 K mol–1 is close to the calculated value of 11.82 cm3 K mol–1 for one magnetically isolated Tb3+ ion (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2). The value of χM T is temperature independent to some degree until 230 K. Then, on further cooling, an abrupt increase appears and reaches a spread maximum of 17.36 cm3 K mol–1 at T = 15.93 K, which indicates ferromagnetic interaction within the chain. After that a sudden decrease in χM T is observed, to the value of 12.14 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Between 16 and 300 K, the linear fit of 1/χM vs. T obeys the Curie–Weiss law 1/χM = (T – θ)/C M, with C M = 11.20 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 14.05 K. For 5, at 300 K, χM T per Dy3+ ion is 14.33 cm3 K mol–1, which is in agreement with the calculated value of 14.15 cm3 K mol–1 (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6H15/2, g = 4/3,). Upon cooling, χM T increases gradually at 5 K and finally increases rapidly on further cooling to a maximum value of 20.61 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, demonstrating ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions in the carboxylate-bridged chain. Between 2 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with C M = 14.38 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 5.36 K. The positive value of θ further confirms the existence of ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions.

Magnetic Properties

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 4-7 were measured on powder samples in an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe at temperatures between 2 and 300 K, and the χM T (χM being the molar magnetic susceptibility) and 1/χM vs T are shown in Figure a,b. For 4, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility reveals that at room temperature, the χM T value of 11.58 cm3 K mol-1 is close to the calculated value of 11.82 cm3 K mol-1 for one magnetically isolated Tb3+ ion (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2). The value of χM T is temperature independent to some degree until 230 K. Then, on further cooling, an abrupt increase appears and reaches a spread maximum of 17.36 cm3 K mol-1 at T = 15.93 K, which indicates ferromagnetic interaction within the chain. After that a sudden decrease in χM T is observed, to the value of 12.14 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. Between 16 and 300 K, the linear fit of 1/χM vs. T obeys the Curie-Weiss law 1/χM = (T - θ)/C M, with C M = 11.20 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 14.05 K. For 5, at 300 K, χM T per Dy3+ ion is 14.33 cm3 K mol-1, which is in agreement with the calculated value of 14.15 cm3 K mol-1 (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6H15/2, g = 4/3,). Upon cooling, χM T increases gradually at 5 K and finally increases rapidly on further cooling to a maximum value of 20.61 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, demonstrating ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions in the carboxylate-bridged chain. Between 2 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie-Weiss law with C M = 14.38 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 5.36 K. The positive value of θ further confirms the existence of ferromagnetic coupling between Dy3+ ions.
